STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
December 26, 2019
James Perlaki
Traverse Place
512 S. Grand Traverse
Flint, MI 48502
RE: License #: CB250201474
Traverse Place
512 S. Grand Traverse
Flint, MI 48502
Dear Mr. Perlaki:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on December
16, 2019. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
ISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that
violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the ISEP and your contract. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not obtained and
maintained compliance for rules found in repeat non-compliance.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(f) If the employee has criminal convictions, the chief
administrator or his or her designee shall complete a written
evaluation of the convictions that addresses the nature of the
conviction, the length of time since the conviction, and the
relationship of the conviction to regulated activity.
(g) A written statement from the employee regarding any
convictions.
One of eight new employee records reviewed showed an ICHAT
for the employee which documented an August 2017 arrest and
count one judgement for operating impaired in Grand Blanc,
Michigan. Another arrest for the same date was documented in
Flint, Michigan which did not show a charge or judgement. The
record did not contain a written evaluation of the conviction by
the chief administrator or his designee, nor a written statement
from the employee about the conviction.
Repeat Violation, Renewal 2018.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(b) A copy of the job description for the staff member's
current position.
Two of 13 employee records reviewed showed the respective
employee was promoted to a new position in 2019. The record
did not show documentation of the employee’s current position.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2016.
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
4

(b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is complying
with the terms of the contract required by R 400.125010,
continues to reside in a safe and acceptable environment, and
is managing expenditures.
The facility’s partially finished basement is used by the youths
for recreation. I observed wires hanging from the ceiling in
several spots. There were also several floor tiles being held
together with duct tape which was coming loose, creating a
safety issue.
R 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information
and documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar
days after placement in independent living and updated at least
once every 90 calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R
400.12420. If the youth has biological children, the service plan
must address the living arrangement for the child or children,
visitation/parenting time with the youth's biological children or a
clear explanation why this is not possible or appropriate.
Two of three open youth records reviewed did not show
compliance to the rule. The service plan either did not contain
time frames for all goals or who would implement the action
steps or the role of the case manager.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2017, Renewal 2016.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
One of three open youth records reviewed did not show
documentation of an updated agreement for the youth, due
October 17, 2019.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
5

None
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
Not applicable.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12202 Policy and procedures(g):
The agency requires all staff to complete 16 hours of orientation and 16 hours of
training annually. The agency was apprised the employee’s annual hours must be
clearly and accurately documented for the employee’s annual reporting period.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12212 Personnel records (e) & (h).
The agency was advised obtaining an updated ICHAT and children service
clearance for a senior employee prior to promotion could be beneficial in terms of
best practice standards.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. The corrective action plan related to the
facility’s 2018 Renewal Inspection, where it received two rule violations. The agency
was not successful with that corrective action plan, as it received repeat citations
related to those rules this inspection.
The agency has a new chief administrator and program coordinator. It continues to
maintain steady placements. The $200,000 Health and Services grant received last
year enabled the agency to open two, two-bedroom rental properties for a Homeless
Prevention Program. This program is to aid youths’ pursuit for independent living
and longer-term permanent housing. At the time of this inspection both rental
properties are vacant.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
6

Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
December 22, 2019
_______________________________________
Lonia Perry Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
December 26, 2019
________________________________________
Linda D. Tansil Date
Area Manager
